items.title: ldap3.core.exceptions.LDAPStartTLSError: automatic start_tls befored bind not successful
items.body:
I recently encountered a problem with ldap3 that seems to be related to the last update of ldap3 from 2.7 to 2.8. I only use the library in an indirect fashion so I first reported the problem there, see  https://github.com/jupyterhub/ldapauthenticator/issues/171 for a detailed discussion. However, I summarize the main points in the following. 

[In these lines](https://github.com/jupyterhub/ldapauthenticator/blob/master/ldapauthenticator/ldapauthenticator.py#L308) of the module a connection is set up. Either ldap3.AUTO_BIND_TLS_BEFORE_BIND or ldap3.AUTO_BIND_NO_TLS is used. They are mapped on the strings 'TLS_BEFORE_BIND' and 'NO_TLS'. 

A [git blame on that file](https://github.com/jupyterhub/ldapauthenticator/blame/master/ldapauthenticator/ldapauthenticator.py#L308) also shows that the code has been there for over a year. With ldap3 version 2.7 that has always worked nicely. If I replace it with ldap3 version 2.8, the following error shows up in the logs:

```
[...]
      File "/opt/conda/lib/python3.6/site-packages/ldapauthenticator/ldapauthenticator.py", line 382, in authenticate
        conn = self.get_connection(userdn, password)
      File "/opt/conda/lib/python3.6/site-packages/ldapauthenticator/ldapauthenticator.py", line 315, in get_connection
        server, user=userdn, password=password, auto_bind=auto_bind
      File "/opt/conda/lib/python3.6/site-packages/ldap3/core/connection.py", line 356, in __init__
        self._do_auto_bind()
      File "/opt/conda/lib/python3.6/site-packages/ldap3/core/connection.py", line 391, in _do_auto_bind
        raise LDAPStartTLSError(error)
    ldap3.core.exceptions.LDAPStartTLSError: automatic start_tls befored bind not successful
```

Furthermore, one user stated that by just re-installing version 2.7 everything works smoothly again [in our ticket discussion](https://github.com/jupyterhub/ldapauthenticator/issues/171#issuecomment-672091454). Do you have an idea where the error stems from? What can we do to resolve this?

**EDIT:** We have frozen https://github.com/jupyterhub/ldapauthenticator to the version 2.7 because the changes introduced in version 2.8 of ldap3 created problems for several users of that library.

items.title: [FEATURE] Option for no line wraps in LDIF export method
items.body:
This is in reference to the method `conn.response_to_ldif()` documented at https://ldap3.readthedocs.io/en/latest/connection.html#connection; to save a click:

> response_to_ldif: a method you can call to convert the response of a search to a LDIF format (ldif-content). It has the following parameters:
>
>         search_result: the result of the search to be converted (defaults to None). If None get the last response received from the Server
>         all_base64: converts all the value to base64 (defaults to False)

What I would like is an additional parameter for this method, to suppress all line wrapping.  For example, instead of this:

```
version: 1
dn: unique_id=xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx,ou=users,o=objects,dc=company,dc
 =com
objectClass: Metadata
objectClass: Person
uid: testuser
```
...I'd like this (note that the `dn` line isn't wrapped):
```
version: 1
dn: unique_id=xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx,ou=users,o=objects,dc=company,dc=com
objectClass: Metadata
objectClass: Person
uid: testuser
```

I'm not referring to the natural line breaks, empty lines, etc. that occur as part of the LDIF file format; just the ones that get inserted to break up long lines.  Basically, what you get with `ldapsearch -o ldif-wrap=no`.

items.title: No response from server when querying two+ large AD groups with ASYNC
items.body:
I'm using the ASYNC strategy to query a list of AD groups for all associated members. The result is a dump of all members names from each AD group. The dump is then used to query AD again for all member attributes. 

When querying at least two AD groups of 4000 users or more, the query_group_members function (below) results in the following error:

`ldap3.core.exceptions.LDAPResponseTimeoutError: no response from server`

It works fine when querying much smaller AD groups or one big AD group at a time.

Are there any potential obvious root causes for this kind of error? I've tried tuning the response timeout with no success.

The code looks like so:

```
    def query_group_members(self, group):
        """Queries single group for its members.

        Args:
            group: AD group
        """
        search_group = escape_filter_chars(group)
        search_filter = f"(&(objectClass=group)(sAMAccountName={search_group}))"
        response_id = self.conn.search(self.search_base,
                                       search_filter,
                                       attributes=['cn', 'member'])
        response, request = self.conn.get_response(response_id)
        result = response[0]['raw_attributes']['member']
        return result

    def query_all_groups(self, ad_groups):
        """Queries member domain names from list of input AD groups.

        Args:
            ad_groups: Input AD groups

        Raises:
            Exception: When worker does not respond.
        """
        group_members = []
        invalid_groups = []
        with concurrent.futures.ThreadPoolExecutor(max_workers=10) as executor:
            future_to_ldap = {executor.submit(self.query_group_members, group): group for group in ad_groups}
            for future in concurrent.futures.as_completed(future_to_ldap):
                searchresults = future_to_ldap[future]
                try:
                    data = future.result()
                    data = list(zip(data, itertools.repeat(searchresults))) # append respective AD group to each member
                    group_members = group_members + data
                except Exception as exc:
                    print('%r generated an exception: %s' % (searchresults, exc))
                    invalid_groups.append(searchresults)
        return group_members, invalid_groups
```

items.title: SASL DIGEST-MD5 incorrect digest-uri
items.body:
When i try to bind to AD:
servers = ldap3.ServerPool(servers=[dc01, dc02, dc03], pool_strategy="ROUND_ROBIN", exhaust=3000)
connect = ldap3.Connection(servers,
                                              fast_decoder=False,
                                              read_only=True,
                                              authentication="SASL",
                                              sasl_mechanism="DIGEST-MD5",
                                              sasl_credentials=(DOMAIN, login, password, None))

connect.bind(read_server_info=True)

I'll get error: 
'message': "80090303: LdapErr: DSID-0C0904DD, comment: The digest-uri does not match any LDAP SPN's registered for this server., data 0, v2580\x00"

Reason is:
Digest_responce string contein incorrect digest-uri: "ldap/" but should be "ldap/**_host_**".
log:
>>LDAPMessage:
>> messageID=8
>> protocolOp=ProtocolOp:
>>  bindRequest=BindRequest:
>>   version=3
>>   name=
>>   authentication=AuthenticationChoice:
>>    sasl=SaslCredentials:
>>     mechanism=DIGEST-MD5
>>     credentials=username="MYUSER",realm="MYREALM",nonce="+Upgraded+v13869bcbfdfe65c3d519d107d507a40f1bd44a3735767d601d815fa537c7b8103240036aa6c3335b2b15d9fca73e46b2c8fca58e61eb2fc34",cnonce="d5232dacf81154adbae052203a6d88db",**digest-uri="ldap/"**,qop=auth,nc=00000001,charset="utf-8",response="e7f0e0e4eabfb30403344a83d328de2e"

In digestMd5.py module, line 97 has hard coded value:
uri = b'ldap/'

FYI: in line 98 has hard coded value qop = b'auth', but in line 114 has:
a2 = b'AUTHENTICATE:' + uri + (':00000000000000000000000000000000' if qop in [b'auth-int', b'auth-conf'] else b'')

1. if always will be False
2. concat bytestring and string will raise exception

When i changed this line 97 to: uri = b'ldap/' + connection.server.host.encode(charset) - digest-uri came correct and that error was gone.

But i got new error that was the same error when i tried to use SASL NTLM: 
'message': '00002028: LdapErr: DSID-0C090202, comment: The server requires binds to turn on integrity checking if SSL\\TLS are not already active on the connection, data 0, v2580\x00'

I checked posability bind to my ldap server with sasl digest-md5 through ldapsearch - all fine.

items.title: Document and possibly check Connection.start_tls return value
items.body:
It seems that [Connection.start_tls](https://github.com/cannatag/ldap3/blob/afa62995290cdcbde2019ecd26f5c961a8b4492d/ldap3/core/connection.py#L1244) returns a boolean. Is it correct that a return value of `False` implies that switching to a secure connection has failed and thus all subsequent commands will be run over a plain connection? If so, this should be documented as it has severe security consequences. Note that [Tls.start_tls](https://github.com/cannatag/ldap3/blob/afa62995290cdcbde2019ecd26f5c961a8b4492d/ldap3/core/tls.py#L245) (which is called from Connection.start_tls) raises an exception for some failures, for others it returns `False`. It's not clear to me when it returns instead of raising an exception. Maybe it should always raise an exception if setting up a secure connection has failed.

The [Connection documentation](https://github.com/cannatag/ldap3/blob/afa62995290cdcbde2019ecd26f5c961a8b4492d/docs/manual/source/connection.rst) currently doesn't document the return value of or exceptions raised from Connection.start_tls.

Note that if not checking the return value of Connection.start_tls is indeed a security issue, there are usages of the function within ldap3 where the return value is not checked, e.g. in [Connection.do_auto_bind](https://github.com/cannatag/ldap3/blob/afa62995290cdcbde2019ecd26f5c961a8b4492d/ldap3/core/connection.py#L374-L378).

items.title: SyntaxError: invalid string prefix in ldap3/utils/port_validators.py"
items.body:
When running tests in Travis CI with Python 3.9a5, I get:
```
Downloading archive: https://storage.googleapis.com/travis-ci-language-archives/python/binaries/ubuntu/16.04/x86_64/python-3.9-dev.tar.bz2
$ curl -sSf --retry 5 -o python-3.9-dev.tar.bz2 ${archive_url}
$ sudo tar xjf python-3.9-dev.tar.bz2 --directory /
$ git clone --depth=50 --branch=master https://github.com/univention/kelvin-rest-api-client.git univention/kelvin-rest-api-client
$ source ~/virtualenv/python3.9-dev/bin/activate
$ python --version
Python 3.9.0a5+

[..]

tests/conftest.py:26: in <module>
    from ldap3 import (
.tox/py39/lib/python3.9/site-packages/ldap3/__init__.py:138: in <module>
    from .core.server import Server
.tox/py39/lib/python3.9/site-packages/ldap3/core/server.py:38: in <module>
    from ..utils.port_validators import check_port, check_port_and_port_list
E     File "/home/travis/build/univention/kelvin-rest-api-client/.tox/py39/lib/python3.9/site-packages/ldap3/utils/port_validators.py", line 20
E       return'Cannot specify both a source port and a source port list'
E            ^
E   SyntaxError: invalid string prefix
```

The missing space between `return` and `'Cannot...` makes Python think all chars of `return` are mean as string prefixes, but `etun` are unknown as that.
Interestingly I cannot reproduce this outside of Travis CI.
Although it seems to be usually ignored, it _is_ a syntax error.

items.title: ssl.CERT_REQUIRED ignored if use_ssl=True
items.body:
I'm connecting to a server whose certificate I have not registered in `certifi.where()` (what exactly location I use is irrelevant. What matters is that certificate verification should happen and fail).    Consider following examples:   
Example 1: configuration according to documentation. No exception is raised due to missing certificate
```
>>> server = Server(LDAP_SERVER, get_info=ALL, tls=Tls(validate=ssl.CERT_REQUIRED, ca_certs_file=certifi.where()), use_ssl=True)
>>> Connection(server, auto_bind=False).start_tls()
False
```
Example 2: expected behavior achieved after `use_ssl` is removed:
```
>>> server = Server(LDAP_SERVER, get_info=ALL, tls=Tls(validate=ssl.CERT_REQUIRED, ca_certs_file=certifi.where()))
>>> Connection(server, auto_bind=False).start_tls()
Traceback (most recent call last):

    self.wrap_socket(connection, do_handshake=True)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/ldap3/core/tls.py", line 204, in wrap_socket
    wrapped_socket = ssl_context.wrap_socket(connection.socket, server_side=False, do_handshake_on_connect=do_handshake)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/eventlet/green/ssl.py", line 402, in wrap_socket
    return GreenSSLSocket(sock, *a, _context=self, **kw)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/eventlet/green/ssl.py", line 91, in __init__
    self.do_handshake()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/eventlet/green/ssl.py", line 270, in do_handshake
    super(GreenSSLSocket, self).do_handshake)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/eventlet/green/ssl.py", line 113, in _call_trampolining
    return func(*a, **kw)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/ssl.py", line 1077, in do_handshake
    self._sslobj.do_handshake()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/ssl.py", line 689, in do_handshake
    self._sslobj.do_handshake()
ssl.SSLError: [SSL: CERTIFICATE_VERIFY_FAILED] certificate verify failed (_ssl.c:852)

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<console>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/ldap3/core/connection.py", line 1264, in start_tls
    if self.server.tls.start_tls(self) and self.strategy.sync:  # for asynchronous connections _start_tls is run by the strategy
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/ldap3/core/tls.py", line 280, in start_tls

items.title: modify_dn() delete_old_dn keyword broken in mock connections
items.body:
[delete_old_dn.patch.zip](https://github.com/cannatag/ldap3/files/4423267/delete_old_dn.patch.zip)

The delete_old_dn flag for modify_dn() is implemented wrong in
the mock connection code.

The flag _should_ control whether or not the attribute(s?)
changed between the new dn and the old dn are updated in the
entry itself.  See: https://ldap.com/the-ldap-modify-dn-operation/

The code instead uses the flag to control whether or not the old
entry is removed from the DIT.

An entirely untested patch is attached.

Note that I am unclear on what the LDAP specification says should
happen to attributes which appear in the old dn but do not appear
in the new dn, when delete_old_dn is True.  Conceivably these
attributes should be removed from the entry.  The code of my
patch does not do this.

items.body:
Hi,

When I make a connection using client_strategy=ldap3.MOCK_SYNC and do an ldapsearch I always get back an objectClass attribute of 'top'.

But when I connect to a openldap 2.4 slapd backend and do the same search
I only get an objectClass: top attribute if a 'top' value has been explicitly
put in an entry.  (Of course if I search for '(objectClass=top)' as a filter I
get all entries.  The 'top' objectclass, and I presume other ancestor
abstract classes, are implied.)

The mock connection should behave like the actual connection
and only return objectClass: top if the value has been explicitly
put into the entry.

Regards,
Karl

items.title: Undocumented 'type' key in connection.response['entries'][0]
items.body:
After calling:

```
server = ldap3.Server.from_definition(
        server_name,
        'examples/dummy_server_info.json',
        'examples/dummy_server_schema.json')
connection = ldap3.Connection(
        server, user=user, password=password,
        return_empty_attributes=False,
	client_strategy=ldap3.MOCK_SYNC)
```
and then adding an entry, a search operation

```
connection.search(
	dn, '(objectclass=*)', attributes=ldap3.ALL_ATTRIBUTES)
```
 returns a "type" key/value in:

```
connection.response['entries'][0]
```

"type" and its value are undocumented.  This makes it more difficult to compare
the response entries with expected responses.

server = ldap3.Server.from_definition(
        server_name,

        'examples/dummy_server_schema.json')
connection = ldap3.Connection(
        server, user=user, password=password,
        return_empty_attributes=False,
	client_strategy=ldap3.MOCK_SYNC)
```
and then adding an entry, a search operation

```

	dn, '(objectclass=*)', attributes=ldap3.ALL_ATTRIBUTES)

 returns the entryDN attribute in:

```

```
"entryDN" is an operational attribute and should not be returned.

(I haven't tried without the MOCK_SYNC strategy.)

items.title: Unclosed socket in case of LDAPBindError Exception
items.body:
Hi,
I am experiencing the following unexpected behavior when I am providing the wrong password or empty password for the ldap3 connection which is running as a **systemd service**.
I am using ldap3 version: **2.6.1**

> import ldap3
> server = ldap3.Server(host=myhost, use_ssl=False, get_info=ldap3.ALL)
> with ldap3.Connection(server=server, user=my_user, password=wrong_pwd, auto_bind=True) as conn:
>     # search query

The socket opened by connection object is not closed and this is running as a service so it continuously opens new socket connections.
In [connection.py](https://github.com/cannatag/ldap3/blob/master/ldap3/core/connection.py#L354) it raises LDAPBindError in the __init__ method because of that it does not enter into the __exit__ method to unbind the connection so the socket remains open.

I have checked the status of socket using the following command in the Linux environment:
> $ sudo netstat -natu | grep -i established | grep 389
> tcp        0      0 x.x.x.x:58152      y.y.y.y:389        ESTABLISHED
> tcp        0      0 x.x.x.x:58148      y.y.y.y:389        ESTABLISHED
> tcp        0      0 x.x.x.x:58140      y.y.y.y:389        ESTABLISHED
> tcp        0      0 x.x.x.x:58144      y.y.y.y:389        ESTABLISHED

And when I am running some unit test cases to check negative cases like an incorrect password or empty password, I am getting following warning message and the connection remains opened:
> ResourceWarning: unclosed <socket.socket fd=5, family=AddressFamily.AF_INET, type=SocketKind.SOCK_STREAM, proto=6, laddr=('x.x.x.x', 57982), raddr=('y.y.y.y', 389)>

And In the case of the correct password, the connection gets closed properly.

items.title: Connection result message with 'data52e' code when username is invalid
items.body:
Hi,

I encountered following issue while working with LDAP3 package: When I am passing wrong credentials (wrong username and wrong password), I am getting same Microsoft Active Directory LDAP Result Codes sub-codes for Bind Response, as when only password is invalid.

My code:


    from ldap3 import Connection, Server, NONE, NTLM
    
    server = Server(url, use_ssl=True, get_info=NONE)
    con = Connection(server, user='ValidID', password='ValidPassword')
    con.bind()
    con.unbind()
    print(con.result)

Result I am getting here:

> {'result': 0, 'description': 'success', 'dn': '', 'message': '', 'referrals': None, 'saslCreds': None, 'type': 'bindResponse'}

Nothing wrong with that. But...

    con = Connection(server, user='InvalidID', password='InvalidPassword')
    con.bind()
    con.unbind()
    print(con.result)

Gives me following result:
> {'result': 49, 'description': 'invalidCredentials', 'dn': '', 'message': '80090308: LdapErr: DSID-0C09042F, comment: AcceptSecurityContext error, data **52e**, v2580\x00', 'referrals': None, 'saslCreds': None, 'type': 'bindResponse'}

According to ldap wiki:

49 | 52e | 1326 | ERROR_LOGON_FAILURE | Returns when username is valid but password/credential is invalid. | Will prevent most other errors from being displayed as noted.
-- | -- | -- | -- | -- | --


In that case I shouldn't be getting "data 52e" message, because username is not valid.

items.title: Incorrect error message
items.body:
The error message in ldap3/utils/conv.py to_unicode takes the type of the unconvertible object twice printing `type` or the objects metaclass instead of its actual type.

    raise UnicodeError("Unable to convert type %s to unicode: %r" % (type(obj).__class__.__name__, obj))

Either `type(obj).__name__` or `obj.__class__.__name__` should do the job.

https://github.com/cannatag/ldap3/blob/9e74a3d6dc17722c5ae6d618012eeb4a41db1836/ldap3/utils/conv.py#L75

items.body:
OS: Solaris 10 sparc, Python 3.6.9, ldap3 2.6.1,

Sample test client code:
```python
import logging
logging.basicConfig(level=logging.DEBUG)

import socket
logging.info('socket.has_ipv6: %s' % socket.has_ipv6)

LDAP_SERVER = 'ldap.foo'

from ldap3 import Connection, Server, IP_V4_ONLY, IP_V4_PREFERRED
from ldap3.utils.log import set_library_log_detail_level, OFF, BASIC, NETWORK, EXTENDED

set_library_log_detail_level(EXTENDED)

ldap_server = Server(host=LDAP_SERVER, mode=IP_V4_ONLY)
#ldap_server = Server(host=LDAP_SERVER, mode=IP_V4_PREFERRED)
#ldap_server = Server(host=LDAP_SERVER)
print(ldap_server)

conn = Connection(server=ldap_server, auto_bind=True)
print(conn)
```


Output:
```
INFO:root:socket.has_ipv6: False
DEBUG:ldap3:ERROR:detail level set to EXTENDED
DEBUG:ldap3:BASIC:instantiated Server: <Server(host='ldap.foo', port=389, use_ssl=False, allowed_referral_hosts=[('*', True)], get_info='SCHEMA', mode='IP_V4_ONLY')>
ldap://ldap.foo:389 - cleartext
DEBUG:ldap3:BASIC:instantiated <SyncStrategy>: <ldap://ldap.foo:389 - cleartext - user: None - not lazy - unbound - closed - <no socket> - tls not started - not listening - No strategy - internal decoder - async - real DSA - not pooled - cannot stream output>
DEBUG:ldap3:BASIC:performing automatic bind for <ldap://ldap.foo:389 - cleartext - user: None - not lazy - unbound - closed - <no socket> - tls not started - not listening - SyncStrategy - internal decoder>
DEBUG:ldap3:NETWORK:opening connection for <ldap://ldap.foo:389 - cleartext - user: None - not lazy - unbound - closed - <no socket> - tls not started - not listening - SyncStrategy - internal decoder>
DEBUG:ldap3:BASIC:address for <ldap://ldap.foo:389 - cleartext> resolved as <[<AddressFamily.AF_INET6: 26>, <SocketKind.SOCK_STREAM: 2>, 6, '', (26, b'\x01\x85\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00')]>
DEBUG:ldap3:ERROR:invalid server address for <ldap://ldap.foo:389 - cleartext - user: None - not lazy - unbound - closed - <no socket> - tls not started - not listening - SyncStrategy - internal decoder>
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "test-ldap.py", line 19, in <module>
    conn = Connection(server=ldap_server, auto_bind=True)
  File "/tps/lib/python3.6/site-packages/ldap3/core/connection.py", line 326, in __init__
    self.do_auto_bind()

I'm not sure if this is another bug, but AD simply ignores my updates on those attributes over and over without any message from ldap3.  To show a simplified version of my code:

```
server = ldap3.Server(server_name, use_ssl=True, get_info=ldap3.ALL)
conn = ldap3.Connection(server, user=username,
        password=password, authentication=ldap3.NTLM,
        auto_bind=True, auto_range=True, auto_referrals=False)
# We specify the base object and the two cursors.
obj_user = ldap3.ObjectDef('user', conn)
r = ldap3.Reader(conn, obj_user, base_dn)
r.search(attributes=attributes_for_search)
w = ldap3.Writer.from_cursor(r)
w = update_ad(employee_dict, w)
w.commit()

def update_ad(employee_dict, write_cursor):
    # Example with 'cn' but this loops over various LDAP attributes.
    for ad_record in write_cursor:
        empl_id = ad_record.employeeId.value
        empl_attr_value = employee_dict[empl_id]['cn']
        if (ad_record, 'cn') != empl_attr_value:
            setattr(ad_record, 'cn', empl_attr_value)

    return write_cursor
```

Then I decided to solve this by issuing `modify_dn` calls when I see changes in **cn**, but (of course) the information already stored in the cursor didn't change:
```
>>> w[12].distinguishedName.value
'CN=Joseph Pesci,OU=Actors,DC=hollywood,DC=internal'
>>> w.connection.modify_dn(w[12].distinguishedName.value,'CN=Joe Pesci')
True
>>> w[12].distinguishedName.value
CN=Joseph Pesci,OU=Actors,DC=hollywood,DC=internal
>>> w.write_commit()
False
>>> w[12].distinguishedName.value
CN=Joseph Pesci,OU=Actors,DC=hollywood,DC=internal
```

If I want to run a unit test on this function, it gets very complicated, because the final state of the cursor won't reflect the actual state of the LDAP server because of the ModifyDn messages.  How am I supposed to do this?  Should the modify_dn code somehow track who's holding data and update their CN and DN (that sounds far-fetched)?  Should I just make those changes in both places (through `entry.cn` and a `modify_dn()` call)?

items.title: Correct way to access and query a trusted domain
items.body:
Hi,

I have an account in my domain **test.priv**.

```
from ldap3 import Server, Connection, ALL, NTLM
 
user = 'test\\user'
user_dn = 'CN=user,OU=Standard Users,OU=New York,DC=test,DC=priv'
password = 'password'
server = Server( 'test.priv', use_ssl=True, get_info=ALL )
```

I have no problem accessing my domain with:
```
conn = Connection( server, user=user, password=password, authentication=NTLM, auto_bind=True )
```
or alternatively with:
```
conn = Connection( server, user_dn, password, auto_bind=True )
```

I tried some tests querying around and everything goes well.

But my domain has a trusted domain I would like to access (bidirectional trust): **services.local**.

If I try:
```
server = Server('services.local', use_ssl=True, get_info=ALL)
conn = Connection( server, user_dn, password, auto_bind=True )
```

I got:

> LDAPSocketOpenError: ('unable to open socket', [(LDAPSocketOpenError("socket ssl wrapping error: [WinError 10054] [...])

or deleting **use_ssl=True** in the server definition:

> LDAPBindError: automatic bind not successful - invalidCredentials

Using NTLM instead:
```
server = Server('services.local', use_ssl=True, get_info=ALL)
conn = Connection( server, user=user, password=password, authentication=NTLM, auto_bind=True )
```

I receive LDAPSocketOpenError again but if I delete **use_ssl=True**, everything works.
Any idea why? Is there a suggested and secure way to connect and query a trusted domain with ldap3?
Thank you very much.
